title: Evening
medium: Acrylic on 300 lb. paper, white frame
blurb: This watercolor captures the softening hues of dusk in a landscape vista, blending plein air observation with memory to evoke a sense of peaceful transition, positioning beauty as a subtle protest against environmental flux.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges. Combining direct perception, memory, and aspiration, her watercolor, gouache, and oil pastel pieces create fresh vistas that feel familiar yet surprising, drawing from terrains like the American West, Italy, and New York’s Hudson Valley.
Prince was born in 1962 and is based in New York and the Hudson Valley. She received her BFA from Rhode Island School of Design and her MFA from Bard College, with a residency at Skowhegan.

Prince has had solo exhibitions linked to residencies at Olana and BAU Institute, Italy. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the New Museum, NY; Galerie Huit, Arles, France; and Draftsmen’s Congress at The New Museum.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/75-lily-prince/

title: Morning
blurb: Depicting the fresh glow of dawn’s light on terrain, this piece translates direct perception into aspirational space, merging Italian, Irish, and American West influences for an uplifting narrative of renewal.

title: Cloud Euphoria
blurb: Billowing clouds swirl in euphoric abstraction, inspired by en plein air sessions to capture fleeting atmospheric joy, blending perception with emotional universality for an immersive skyward gaze.
artist_bio: Lily Prince’s plein air-inspired works translate observational landscapes into personal expressions of universal significance, viewing beauty as a form of protest amid environmental and societal challenges. title: Cosmic Lotus Moth
medium: Archival pigment inks on cotton rag paper with salt crystals, gold leaf, and color pencil
blurb: Blending lotus blooms with moth forms in a starry cosmos, this work imagines fluid connections between earthly flora and celestial realms, inspired by 19th-century naturalists to fluctuate between microcosmic details and macroscopic wonders. Framed dimensions: 63.5 × 53.5 × 3.1 cm.
artist_bio: Christine Nguyen’s work draws on nature, science, and the cosmos, imagining fluid connections between ocean depths and outer space through an organic prism. Her practice, inspired by 19th-century naturalists like Ernst Haeckel and Anna Atkins, extracts curiosities from the natural world to create meditative, micro-macroscopic visions blending biology, philosophy, and mystery.

Nguyen was born in 1977 in Mountain View, California, and resides in Aurora, Colorado, and Long Beach, California. She received her BFA from California State University, Long Beach, and her MFA from the University of California, Irvine.

Nguyen has had solo exhibitions tied to residencies at Montello Foundation, NV, and Pacific Bonsai Museum, WA. She has participated in recent group exhibitions at the J. Paul Getty Museum and Armand Hammer Museum, with works in collections including the Getty Research Institute and Long Beach Museum of Art.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/76-christine-nguyen/

title: Cosmic Rabbit Light
blurb: Cosmic Rabbit Light situates a delicate animal form within a suspended, luminous field, where terrestrial life appears to drift through a cosmological atmosphere. The rabbit—rendered with quiet attentiveness—functions as both subject and symbol, evoking vulnerability, intuition, and cyclical renewal. Nguyen surrounds the figure with translucent arcs, floating botanical motifs, and particulate marks that suggest motion without urgency, as if time itself has softened. Working on Mylar allows light to pass through the composition, activating layers of drawing, pigment, and photographic reference into a single, breathing surface. The image oscillates between the microscopic and the infinite, inviting the viewer to read the rabbit simultaneously as a creature of the earth and a celestial traveler—an emissary between fragile ecosystems and expansive, unseen realms.
artist_bio: Born in 1977, Christine Nguyen, based in Colorado and California, draws upon nature, sciences, and the cosmos in her luminous, photo-based drawings and mixed media works. Her philosophy emphasizes holistic symbiotic relationships, imagining realms beyond conventional readings—leaning into mysterious underwater and cosmic themes. Exhibitions like Radical Futures (2024) and Lightness Within the Cosmic Universe (2021) highlight her ability to transform the natural world into ethereal, reflective universes that encourage pause and deeper connection.
View Full Artist Profile: https://www.532gallery.com/artists/76-christine-nguyen/

title: Cosmic Owl Light
blurb: In Cosmic Owl Light, Nguyen presents the owl as a contemplative presence suspended within a radiant, atmospheric space. Traditionally associated with perception, knowledge, and nocturnal awareness, the owl appears here not as a predator, but as a guardian—perched within a nest-like vortex of line, light, and drifting organic forms. The composition unfolds vertically, drawing the eye upward through layers of translucent color, gestural arcs, and subtle constellations of mark-making. The Mylar surface enhances the sensation of weightlessness, allowing light to refract across overlapping elements and creating a sense of depth that feels both underwater and cosmic. The work invites prolonged looking, rewarding stillness with the impression that the image itself is slowly breathing, watching, and holding space.
artist_bio: Born in 1977, Christine Nguyen, based in Colorado and California, draws upon nature, sciences, and the cosmos in her luminous, photo-based drawings and mixed media works. Her philosophy emphasizes holistic symbiotic relationships, imagining realms beyond conventional readings—leaning into mysterious underwater and cosmic themes. title: Cosmic Blue Flower Light
blurb: Cosmic Blue Flower Light centers on a radiant, multi-petaled bloom that appears to float between states of emergence and dissolution. Rendered in cool blues and softened linework, the flower becomes a conduit through which light, memory, and energy circulate. Rather than depicting a specific species, Nguyen abstracts botanical form into a symbolic structure—part organism, part cosmic diagram. Surrounding arcs, floating points, and subtle chromatic shifts create the impression of a living system in motion, as if the flower is both receiving and transmitting energy across space. The translucency of Mylar amplifies this effect, allowing layers to hover rather than settle. The work reflects Nguyen’s ongoing exploration of nature as a portal—where minute physical details open onto expansive, meditative visions of interconnectedness.
artist_bio: Born in 1977, Christine Nguyen, based in Colorado and California, draws upon nature, sciences, and the cosmos in her luminous, photo-based drawings and mixed media works. title: Candy Girl
blurb: A candy-hued figure pops with playful energy, fusing Mongolian motifs with consumerist whimsy to explore identity in a vibrant, graphic narrative.
artist_bio: Zayasaikhan Sambuu’s vibrant paintings fuse pop culture with Mongolian traditions, using candy-like colors and playful motifs to explore themes of consumerism, identity, and modern life. His works balance bold graphic elements with subtle cultural commentary, creating energetic compositions that invite viewers to reflect on global influences through a whimsical lens.
Zayasaikhan Sambuu was born in 1975 in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, and lives and works there. He received his education at the Mongolian University of Arts and Culture.

title: Candy Girl 2
blurb: Sequel to the series, this piece layers sweet colors and bold forms, commenting on cultural contrasts through Sambuu’s signature pop-traditional blend.

title: Sweet on You
blurb: Sugary tones and affectionate motifs entwine, inviting reflection on modern sweetness amid global influences, in Sambuu’s energetic style.
